questions.stem: A sleep medicine specialist reviews a polysomnography report showing brief bursts of 12-14 Hz activity and large, sharp waveforms occurring during a patient's sleep recording. These EEG features are most characteristic of which sleep stage?
questions.explanation: Sleep spindles (brief 12-14 Hz bursts generated by the thalamus) and K-complexes (large, sharp waveforms) are the defining EEG features of NREM Stage 2 (N2). N2 comprises the largest proportion of total sleep time (approximately 45-55%). Sleep spindles are believed to play a role in memory consolidation and protecting sleep from external disturbances. K-complexes represent cortical responses to external stimuli and may function in sleep maintenance.

questions.stem: A patient with Type 1 narcolepsy experiences sudden episodes of muscle tone loss triggered by strong emotions such as laughter. This symptom is most likely caused by a deficiency in which neuropeptide?
questions.explanation: Type 1 narcolepsy involves deficiency of hypocretin (also called orexin), a neuropeptide produced by the lateral hypothalamus that promotes wakefulness. The loss of hypocretin-producing neurons, believed to result from autoimmune destruction, causes excessive daytime sleepiness and cataplexy -- the sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by strong emotions. Cataplexy is pathognomonic for Type 1 narcolepsy and distinguishes it from Type 2 narcolepsy (which lacks cataplexy).

questions.stem: A 68-year-old man's bed partner reports that he frequently acts out his dreams, sometimes shouting and making violent arm movements during sleep. A sleep study confirms loss of normal muscle atonia during REM sleep. This condition is most strongly associated with future development of which disorder?

options.text: Parkinson's disease or Lewy body dementia

questions.explanation: REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) involves loss of normal muscle atonia during REM sleep, allowing individuals to physically act out their dreams. RBD is a strong prodromal marker for synucleinopathies -- a significant percentage of patients (over 80% in long-term follow-up studies) with RBD eventually develop Parkinson's disease or Lewy body dementia. This association is high-yield for the EPPP and represents one of the strongest known prodromal markers in neurodegeneration.

questions.stem: According to the two-process model of sleep regulation (Borbely, 1982), which interaction best explains why a person can experience a 'second wind' late at night despite being awake for 18 hours?

options.text: Process S (homeostatic drive) has dissipated after prolonged wakefulness
Process C (circadian alerting signal) transiently overcomes the high homeostatic sleep drive
Melatonin secretion increases alertness at night
The suprachiasmatic nucleus shuts down after 18 hours of wakefulness

questions.explanation: Borbely's two-process model proposes that sleep is regulated by the interaction of Process S (homeostatic sleep drive, which builds during wakefulness through adenosine accumulation) and Process C (circadian alerting signal from the SCN). A 'second wind' occurs when the circadian alerting signal transiently overcomes the high homeostatic sleep drive. Process S does not dissipate during wakefulness -- it continues to build. Melatonin promotes sleepiness, not alertness. The SCN continues to function throughout wakefulness.

questions.stem: A parent brings her 6-year-old child to a pediatrician after the child has been having episodes of sitting up in bed screaming with tachycardia and sweating, typically during the first third of the night. The child has no memory of these events. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Night terrors (sleep terrors) are NREM parasomnias that occur during Stage 3 slow-wave sleep, typically in the first third of the night when SWS predominates. They are characterized by sudden arousal with intense autonomic activation (tachycardia, sweating, screaming) and amnesia for the event. Night terrors are most common in children and usually resolve with maturation. They are distinguished from nightmares (which occur during REM sleep in the last third of the night, with full recall of dream content) and from REM sleep behavior disorder (which involves dream enactment during REM sleep and predominantly affects older adults).

questions.stem: Which of the following are accurate descriptions of the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) and circadian rhythm regulation? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: The SCN is located in the anterior hypothalamus directly above the optic chiasm
The SCN receives light information via the retinohypothalamic tract from melanopsin-containing retinal ganglion cells
The SCN projects to the pineal gland, which secretes melatonin during darkness
SCN damage enhances circadian rhythmicity, producing more regular sleep-wake cycles
The SCN has an endogenous period of approximately 24 hours in humans

questions.explanation: The SCN is the master circadian clock located in the anterior hypothalamus above the optic chiasm. It receives light input via the retinohypothalamic tract from specialized melanopsin-containing retinal ganglion cells (not rod/cone photoreceptors). The SCN projects to the pineal gland to regulate melatonin secretion (increased during darkness, suppressed by light). SCN damage abolishes (not enhances) circadian rhythmicity. The endogenous period in humans is approximately 24.2 hours, requiring daily light-mediated entrainment to stay synchronized with the 24-hour day.

questions.stem: Which of the following correctly distinguish night terrors from nightmares? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Night terrors occur during NREM Stage 3 (slow-wave sleep), while nightmares occur during REM sleep
Night terrors typically occur in the first third of the night, while nightmares typically occur in the last third
Night terrors involve amnesia for the event, while nightmares are recalled in vivid detail
Night terrors are more common in adults, while nightmares are more common in children
Night terrors involve intense autonomic arousal (tachycardia, sweating), while nightmares typically do not

questions.explanation: Night terrors and nightmares differ on multiple dimensions. Night terrors: occur during NREM Stage 3 SWS, in the first third of the night when SWS predominates, involve intense autonomic arousal, and are followed by amnesia for the event. Nightmares: occur during REM sleep, in the last third of the night when REM predominates, involve vivid dream recall, and typically lack intense autonomic arousal. Night terrors are more common in CHILDREN (not adults), while nightmares occur across the lifespan.

questions.stem: Regarding the relationship between sleep and memory consolidation, which statements are supported by current research? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Slow-wave sleep (SWS) is particularly important for consolidating declarative (explicit) memories
REM sleep appears especially important for consolidating procedural and emotional memories
Sleep spindles during N2 correlate with learning gains and may facilitate hippocampal-to-neocortical transfer
Memory consolidation occurs exclusively during REM sleep, with no contribution from NREM stages
Most slow-wave sleep occurs in the first third of the night, while most REM occurs in the last third

questions.explanation: Sleep-dependent memory consolidation involves multiple stages. SWS is critical for declarative memory consolidation through coordinated slow oscillations, hippocampal ripples, and thalamocortical spindles. REM sleep is important for procedural and emotional memory consolidation. N2 sleep spindles correlate with learning and facilitate information transfer from hippocampus to neocortex. Memory consolidation is NOT exclusive to REM -- both NREM and REM contribute. The temporal distribution (SWS early, REM late) explains why early-night and late-night sleep disruptions affect different memory types.

questions.stem: Which of the following are characteristic features of narcolepsy Type 1? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Deficiency of hypocretin (orexin) produced by the lateral hypothalamus
Sleep-onset REM periods (SOREMPs) occurring within 15 minutes of sleep onset
Excessive daytime sleepiness resistant to adequate nighttime sleep

questions.explanation: Type 1 narcolepsy features: (1) cataplexy (pathognomonic -- sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by emotions), (2) hypocretin/orexin deficiency from autoimmune destruction of lateral hypothalamic neurons, (3) sleep-onset REM periods (SOREMPs) within 15 minutes of sleep onset (normal REM latency is about 90 minutes), and (4) excessive daytime sleepiness. The SCN is not destroyed in narcolepsy -- the disorder involves loss of hypocretin-producing neurons in the lateral hypothalamus, not the SCN.

questions.stem: Which of the following accurately describe developmental changes in sleep architecture across the lifespan? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Newborns spend approximately 50% of sleep time in REM (active sleep) and have a polyphasic sleep pattern
Adolescents experience a circadian phase delay, naturally tending toward later bedtimes and wake times
Older adults show decreased slow-wave sleep, reduced sleep efficiency, and an advanced circadian phase
The proportion of REM sleep increases steadily from birth through old age
NREM parasomnias (night terrors, sleepwalking) peak in childhood and usually resolve with maturation

questions.explanation: Developmental sleep changes: Newborns sleep 16-18 hours/day with approximately 50% REM and polyphasic patterns. Adolescents show circadian phase delay (later bedtime tendency). Older adults show decreased SWS, reduced sleep efficiency, more awakenings, and advanced circadian phase (earlier bedtime/wake time). The proportion of REM sleep DECREASES (not increases) from approximately 50% in newborns to approximately 20-25% in adults, remaining relatively stable thereafter. NREM parasomnias peak in childhood due to high amounts of SWS and typically resolve with maturation.

questions.stem: Match each sleep stage with its primary EEG pattern.
questions.explanation: Relaxed wakefulness (eyes closed) is characterized by alpha waves (8-13 Hz). NREM Stage 1 shows theta waves (4-7 Hz), representing the transition from wakefulness to sleep. NREM Stage 3 (slow-wave sleep) is dominated by high-amplitude delta waves (0.5-4 Hz). REM sleep shows desynchronized, low-amplitude activity resembling wakefulness (hence 'paradoxical sleep'), similar to beta waves. NREM Stage 2 (not listed) shows theta waves with distinctive sleep spindles and K-complexes.

questions.stem: Match each sleep disorder with the neurotransmitter or neuropeptide most directly implicated in its pathophysiology.
questions.explanation: Narcolepsy Type 1 results from deficiency of hypocretin (orexin) due to autoimmune destruction of lateral hypothalamic neurons. Insomnia is associated with excessive cortical arousal (hyperarousal model), explaining why CBT-I targets cognitive and physiological arousal. Delayed sleep-wake phase disorder involves timing dysregulation of melatonin secretion relative to desired sleep-wake schedule. REM sleep behavior disorder involves dysfunction of the brainstem glycinergic/GABAergic systems that normally produce muscle atonia during REM sleep.

questions.stem: For each sleep stage, select ALL features that accurately characterize it.

columns.text: Predominates in the first third of the night
Predominates in the last third of the night

questions.explanation: NREM Stage 2 is characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes. NREM Stage 3 (SWS) predominates in the first third of the night and is the primary stage during which growth hormone is released. REM sleep predominates in the last third of the night, with REM periods becoming progressively longer. NREM Stage 1 is a brief transitional stage at sleep onset that does not predominate at any particular time of night and is not associated with spindles, K-complexes, or growth hormone release.

questions.stem: For each theory of dreaming, select ALL claims that are consistent with that theory.

columns.text: Dreams result from random brainstem activation
Dreams serve a functional adaptive purpose

questions.explanation: Freud's theory holds that dreams have meaningful content (disguised unconscious wishes), but does not attribute them to random activation or claim a learning function. Activation-synthesis theory proposes dreams result from random brainstem activation that the cortex attempts to interpret -- dreams have no inherent meaning. Information-processing theory claims dreams serve the functional purpose of consolidating memories and facilitating learning. Threat simulation theory (Revonsuo) proposes dreams have both meaningful content (threat scenarios) and an adaptive function (rehearsing threat-avoidance behaviors), but does not specifically focus on memory consolidation.

questions.stem: The master circadian clock is the {{blank1}}, located in the anterior hypothalamus. It receives light information via the retinohypothalamic tract and projects to the {{blank2}}, which secretes melatonin during {{blank3}}. Melatonin secretion is suppressed by exposure to {{blank4}}, which is why screen use before bed can delay sleep onset.
questions.explanation: The SCN is the master circadian clock in the anterior hypothalamus. It projects to the pineal gland, which secretes melatonin during darkness (not daylight). Melatonin promotes sleep onset and is suppressed by light exposure, particularly blue-wavelength light. This is why evening screen use (which emits blue light) can suppress melatonin and delay sleep onset, contributing to insomnia and circadian disruption.

questions.stem: In Borbely's two-process model, {{blank1}} is the homeostatic sleep drive that builds during wakefulness through accumulation of {{blank2}}, while {{blank3}} is the circadian alerting signal driven by the SCN. Sleep occurs when Process S is {{blank4}} and Process C permits sleep.
questions.explanation: In Borbely's two-process model, Process S (homeostatic sleep drive) builds progressively during wakefulness through accumulation of adenosine and other sleep-promoting substances (caffeine blocks adenosine receptors, counteracting Process S). Process C (circadian alerting signal) is driven by the SCN and promotes wakefulness during the day. Sleep occurs when Process S is high (after prolonged wakefulness) and Process C permits sleep (circadian alerting signal decreases at night).

questions.stem: A 45-year-old woman presents to a sleep clinic reporting difficulty falling asleep, racing thoughts at bedtime, and daytime fatigue for the past six months. She reports that she has been spending increasing time in bed trying to fall asleep and has begun associating her bedroom with frustration and wakefulness.

options.text: Conditioned arousal to the bedroom environment (bed = wakefulness)
Excessive time in bed reducing sleep efficiency
Hypocretin deficiency in the lateral hypothalamus
Obstructive upper airway collapse during sleep
Stimulus control therapy (bed for sleep only; leave bed if not asleep within 20 minutes)
Sleep restriction to increase sleep efficiency by matching time in bed to actual sleep time
Long-term benzodiazepine prescription as the first-line treatment
CPAP therapy to maintain airway patency

questions.explanation: This patient presents with chronic insomnia disorder perpetuated by conditioned arousal (associating the bed with wakefulness and frustration) and excessive time in bed (reducing sleep efficiency). CBT-I is the first-line treatment (not pharmacotherapy). Key components include stimulus control (re-associating the bed with sleep by leaving bed when unable to sleep) and sleep restriction (limiting time in bed to match actual sleep time, thereby increasing sleep drive and sleep efficiency). CPAP is for sleep apnea, and long-term benzodiazepines are not recommended as first-line insomnia treatment.

questions.stem: A neurologist evaluates a 22-year-old college student who reports excessive daytime sleepiness, episodes of sudden muscle weakness during laughter, vivid hallucinations when falling asleep, and an inability to move upon waking. A Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT) reveals sleep-onset REM periods.

options.text: Autoimmune destruction of hypocretin-producing neurons in the lateral hypothalamus
Excessive melatonin production throughout the day
Cataplexy (sudden muscle tone loss) triggered by emotions, especially laughter
Shortened REM latency with sleep-onset REM periods (SOREMPs)
Episodes of upper airway obstruction during sleep
Sleep terrors occurring during slow-wave sleep

questions.explanation: This presentation -- excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy (muscle weakness with laughter), hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis, and SOREMPs on MSLT -- is classic narcolepsy Type 1. The pathophysiology involves autoimmune destruction of hypocretin (orexin)-producing neurons in the lateral hypothalamus, resulting in loss of wakefulness-promoting orexin signaling. Expected features include cataplexy (pathognomonic for Type 1) and shortened REM latency with SOREMPs. The SCN is not destroyed, and excessive melatonin is not the mechanism.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe the effects of chronic sleep deprivation.
questions.passage: Chronic sleep deprivation has widespread effects on cognitive and physical functioning. [Sleep-deprived individuals show increased amygdala activity and decreased prefrontal cortex regulation, leading to heightened emotional reactivity]. [Sleep deprivation selectively impairs procedural memory while leaving declarative memory completely intact]. [Chronic sleep loss impairs attention, working memory, decision-making, and immune function]. [Growth hormone, primarily secreted during slow-wave sleep, is reduced by sleep deprivation]. [Severe prolonged sleep deprivation can produce perceptual disturbances, paranoia, and psychotic-like symptoms]. [Sleep deprivation has no effect on emotional processing or mood regulation].

highlightableSegments.text: Sleep-deprived individuals show increased amygdala activity and decreased prefrontal cortex regulation, leading to heightened emotional reactivity
Sleep deprivation selectively impairs procedural memory while leaving declarative memory completely intact
Chronic sleep loss impairs attention, working memory, decision-making, and immune function
Growth hormone, primarily secreted during slow-wave sleep, is reduced by sleep deprivation
Severe prolonged sleep deprivation can produce perceptual disturbances, paranoia, and psychotic-like symptoms
Sleep deprivation has no effect on emotional processing or mood regulation

questions.explanation: Sleep deprivation increases amygdala reactivity with reduced prefrontal regulation (h1 - correct). It does NOT selectively impair procedural memory while leaving declarative intact -- both are affected, and declarative memory consolidation (dependent on SWS) is particularly vulnerable (h2 - incorrect). Chronic sleep loss broadly impairs cognitive function and immune response (h3 - correct). Growth hormone secretion is tied to SWS and is reduced by sleep deprivation (h4 - correct). Severe deprivation can produce psychotic-like symptoms (h5 - correct). Sleep deprivation significantly impairs emotional processing and mood regulation (h6 - incorrect).

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe sleep-related changes across the lifespan.
questions.passage: Sleep architecture changes dramatically from birth through old age. [Newborns spend approximately 50% of their sleep time in REM sleep, which decreases to about 20-25% by adulthood]. [Adolescents experience a circadian phase delay, naturally tending toward later bedtimes, which conflicts with early school start times]. [Older adults show increased slow-wave sleep and improved sleep efficiency compared to younger adults]. [The proportion of NREM Stage 2 sleep remains relatively stable across the adult lifespan]. [Shortened REM latency (time from sleep onset to first REM period) is a biological marker of major depressive disorder]. [Melatonin production increases with age, which is why older adults typically sleep longer].

highlightableSegments.text: Newborns spend approximately 50% of their sleep time in REM sleep, which decreases to about 20-25% by adulthood
Adolescents experience a circadian phase delay, naturally tending toward later bedtimes, which conflicts with early school start times
Older adults show increased slow-wave sleep and improved sleep efficiency compared to younger adults
The proportion of NREM Stage 2 sleep remains relatively stable across the adult lifespan
Shortened REM latency (time from sleep onset to first REM period) is a biological marker of major depressive disorder
Melatonin production increases with age, which is why older adults typically sleep longer

questions.explanation: Newborns do spend approximately 50% of sleep in REM, declining to 20-25% in adults (h1 - correct). Adolescent circadian phase delay is well-documented and conflicts with school schedules (h2 - correct). Older adults show DECREASED (not increased) slow-wave sleep and REDUCED (not improved) sleep efficiency (h3 - incorrect). NREM Stage 2 proportions remain relatively stable in adults (h4 - correct). Shortened REM latency is indeed a biological marker of major depression (h5 - correct). Melatonin production DECREASES (not increases) with age, contributing to age-related sleep difficulties (h6 - incorrect).

questions.stem: Arrange the sleep stages in the typical order they occur during the first complete sleep cycle of the night, from sleep onset to the end of the first cycle.

items.text: NREM Stage 1 (N1): Light sleep with theta waves, hypnagogic hallucinations
NREM Stage 2 (N2): Sleep spindles and K-complexes appear
NREM Stage 3 (N3): Deep slow-wave sleep with delta waves; longest N3 period of the night
Brief return to NREM Stage 2 as the brain transitions out of deep sleep
Brief NREM Stage 1 transition before REM onset
First REM period: shortest REM episode of the night (~10 minutes)

questions.explanation: The first sleep cycle progresses from N1 (light transition) to N2 (spindles and K-complexes) to N3 (deep slow-wave sleep -- the longest N3 period occurs in the first cycle). The cycle then reverses through lighter NREM stages (N2, then brief N1) before entering the first REM period, which is typically the shortest of the night (approximately 10 minutes). As the night progresses, N3 periods shorten while REM periods lengthen. A complete cycle lasts approximately 90 minutes.

questions.stem: Arrange the following events in the correct sequence of circadian rhythm regulation, from environmental light detection to sleep-promoting effects.

items.text: Light enters the eye and is detected by melanopsin-containing retinal ganglion cells
Photic information travels via the retinohypothalamic tract to the SCN
The SCN entrains its endogenous ~24-hour rhythm to the light-dark cycle
As darkness falls, the SCN signals the pineal gland to begin melatonin synthesis
Melatonin is released into the bloodstream, promoting sleep onset and lowering body temperature
Morning light exposure suppresses melatonin, promoting wakefulness and resetting the cycle

questions.explanation: Circadian regulation follows a precise sequence: (1) specialized melanopsin-containing retinal ganglion cells detect light, (2) photic information travels through the retinohypothalamic tract to the SCN, (3) the SCN entrains its endogenous rhythm to the external light-dark cycle, (4) during darkness, the SCN signals the pineal gland to synthesize melatonin, (5) melatonin promotes sleep onset and thermoregulatory changes, and (6) morning light suppresses melatonin and resets the cycle. This explains why light exposure timing is critical for treating circadian rhythm disorders.

questions.stem: A sleep researcher tracks the changing proportions of slow-wave sleep (SWS) and REM sleep across a typical eight-hour night of sleep in a healthy young adult.
questions.question: What clinically relevant conclusion can be drawn from this distribution pattern?

options.text: Disruptions to early-night sleep primarily affect REM-dependent emotional processing

Disruptions to early-night sleep primarily affect SWS-dependent declarative memory consolidation, while disruptions to late-night sleep primarily affect REM-dependent procedural and emotional processing
SWS and REM are equally distributed throughout the night with no preferential timing
Only REM sleep contributes to memory consolidation, making early-night sleep irrelevant

questions.explanation: The data show that SWS dominates the first two cycles (40 and 30 minutes) and nearly disappears by the end of the night, while REM periods progressively lengthen (from 10 to 50 minutes). This uneven distribution has direct clinical implications: early-night sleep disruptions (from shift work, early alarm clocks, or sleep disorders) primarily sacrifice SWS and therefore impair declarative memory consolidation and growth hormone release. Late-night sleep disruptions primarily sacrifice REM sleep and therefore impair procedural learning and emotional memory processing.

questions.stem: A developmental psychologist examines sleep architecture data across different age groups in a cross-sectional study.
questions.question: Which conclusion is best supported by these developmental data?

options.text: REM sleep percentage increases linearly with age, reflecting greater cognitive processing needs
Both total sleep time and REM percentage decline across the lifespan, with the most dramatic REM decline occurring in early development, consistent with theories linking REM to brain maturation
Total sleep time remains constant while only REM percentage changes
The data show no systematic relationship between age and sleep architecture

questions.explanation: The data show two clear developmental trends: (1) total sleep time decreases from 16 hours in newborns to 6 hours at age 80, and (2) REM percentage drops most dramatically in early development (50% at birth to 23% by age 15), then stabilizes with modest further decline. The steep early decline in REM percentage is consistent with theories that REM sleep plays a critical role in brain maturation and neural development during infancy and early childhood, when synaptic pruning and neural circuit formation are at their peak.

questions.stem: Categorize each sleep phenomenon as occurring primarily during NREM sleep, REM sleep, or the wake-sleep transition.

items.text: Sleepwalking (somnambulism) and night terrors
Vivid, narrative dreaming with muscle atonia
Hypnagogic hallucinations and hypnic jerks
Growth hormone release (primarily during N3)
REM sleep behavior disorder (dream enactment)
Sleep paralysis upon awakening

questions.explanation: NREM sleep phenomena: sleepwalking and night terrors occur during N3 (SWS), and growth hormone is primarily released during N3. REM sleep phenomena: vivid narrative dreaming occurs with normal muscle atonia, and REM sleep behavior disorder involves pathological loss of this atonia allowing dream enactment. Wake-sleep transition phenomena: hypnagogic hallucinations and hypnic jerks occur at sleep onset (N1 entry), and sleep paralysis occurs at the transition from REM sleep to wakefulness (temporary persistence of REM atonia into wakefulness).

questions.stem: Categorize each sleep disorder according to its primary underlying mechanism.

items.text: Delayed sleep-wake phase disorder (common in adolescents)
Narcolepsy Type 1 (hypocretin deficiency with cataplexy)
Obstructive sleep apnea (upper airway collapse)
Jet lag disorder (internal clock misaligned with time zone)
REM sleep behavior disorder (loss of glycinergic REM atonia)
Central sleep apnea (brainstem fails to signal breathing)

questions.explanation: Circadian rhythm dysfunction: delayed sleep-wake phase disorder involves a shifted circadian clock (common in adolescents), and jet lag involves misalignment between the internal clock and the destination time zone. Neuropeptide/neurotransmitter dysfunction: narcolepsy Type 1 results from hypocretin (orexin) deficiency, and REM sleep behavior disorder involves dysfunction of glycinergic/GABAergic brainstem circuits that normally maintain muscle atonia during REM. Airway/respiratory dysfunction: obstructive sleep apnea involves mechanical upper airway collapse, and central sleep apnea involves failure of brainstem respiratory drive signals.
